Table 1. IPID Selection Methods’ Space Complexities.

<sup class="ltx_sup" id="S4.T1.6.3.3.1">∗</sup>The Windows implementation of per-destination selection technically has unbounded space complexity, but this table lists the expected memory usage for Windows Server v1904 (see text).
∗The Windows implementation of per-destination selection technically has unbounded space complexity, but this table lists the expected memory usage for Windows Server v1904 (see text).

references: For space complexity, we consider all data structures that a selection method stores between IPID requests (see Table 1). Globally incrementing selection stores a single 16-bit counter. Per-connection and per-destination selection store one 16-bit counter per active connection or destination, respectively. There are ∼ similar-to \sim ∼ 3.7 billion unreserved IP addresses and thus there could be at most as many destination counters; the maximum number of connection counters is even larger since connections also consider source and destination ports and protocol numbers. In practice, Windows fixes a ∼ similar-to \sim ∼ ∼ ∼ similar-to similar-to similar-to\sim \sim∼ ∼3.7 billion unreserved IP addresses and thus there could be at most as many destination counters; the maximum number of connection counters is even larger since connections also consider source and destination ports and protocol numbers. Linux treats connection counters as acceptably small members of its socket data structures, and implements per-bucket selection by storing one 16-bit counter and one 32-bit last access timestamp for each of its (Klein, 2022, 2024).
